Nomenclature is imprecise but why don't you skip the cow and defer to the 'cut, fraction-cut' adapter.  I picked 3 up for as low as $25 in the 24/29 range.  It's akin to the decompression cycles since while momentarily holding the pot under vacuum you deftly replace the receiving flask with the next.  Sure the price is wild @2-500 price ranges but these china versions are solid.

I'm sorry, there are big mistakes. Adding a saturated solution of NaHCO3 or Na2CO3 to almond oil you get a little soap and Cannizzaro's reaction converting benzaldehyde in benzoic acid and benzilic alcohol. It's true you have sodium benzoate,  however you can't convert it to benzaldehyde (it's a reaction of reduction) by adding magnesium sulfate. So I don't know you have distilled, maybe it's benzilic alcohol or propan-1,2,3-olo. You didn't say the temperature of the distillation.

NileRed why don't you try making benzaldehyde from Benzyl alcohol using pyridinium chlorochromate or P.C.C in DCM ? You can make your own P.C.C...buy some Vitamin B- Niacin from the health food shop and pyrolyse it, via  a distillation..and CrO3.if you can't source chromium  oxide you can make it fairly easily from any chromate or dichromate with conc. sulfuric, and the only other reagent is hydrochloric acid. You could even get real clever and substitute the pyridine with quinoline, easily made by the Skraup synthesis, just Aniline with glycerol and conc. sulfuric...quinolinium chlorochromate is just as effective as P.C.C..the yield of the oxidation is high, over 80% because the aldehyde is not in an aqueous form and thus does not form a hydrate, which are much more susceptible to oxidation.

Hey Nile, i was curious about using the starting EO (such as the one in this video) for use in soap fragrance. I was unaware of the benzoic acid that forms as a contaminant from storage and whatnot. The soap i was looking to make would be a hard castile using NaOH as the base. Just to confirm, any benzoic acid, that may potentially be in whatever oil I may find, should be neutralized upon contact w the base? Also, how about the potential long-term storage of almond scented bars of soap? Would there be any potential risk of the miniscule amounts of benzaldehyde (per bar) becoming oxidized into any harmful benzoic acid in time? Should I be concerned w this @ all? Then again, I could imagine how the chemical nature of the soap might prevent oxidation on some level... yet I'm new to the soap-making world. Anyhow...
